children.text: The words
analog
and
digital
are used a lot, but what do they mean? In this section, we look at those two worlds, which you use every day.
Analog
The living, breathing world is basically analog. What does that mean? A
signal
is a varying wave, typically carrying information we care about. Sound is a great example of a signal.

How Does Sound Work?
Sound is a great example of an analog process. The signal goes from one medium to the next, but keeps its basic shape.

children.alt: Violin sound waves, to air, then to eardrum

children.text: We'll follow the path of a sound signal from a violin to eardrum as an example of an analog system. Sound is made of vibrations in the air over time—essentially small changes in air pressure over time. When a violin plays, the wood top and back of the instrument flex in and out, producing little ripples of pressure in the air that flow out from the violin. When the ripples hit an ear drum, the ear drum flexes back and forth, reproducing the flexing of the violin top. This is a very analog sequence: the signal goes from the wooden violin to the air to the eardrum, keeping its basic shape.

Analog Technology
Analog is the pre-digital way of transmitting or storing a signal. The first telephone was very analog. We'll follow the trail of the sound signal through an early telephone:
Speaking person makes sound waves in the air.
Microphone converts sound waves into electrical waves.
Electrical waves go down the wire to the other phone.
At the other end, a speaker has magnets connected to a paper cone, converting the incoming electrical wave back into asound wave.

The key feature of analog signaling is one-to-one correspondence. Variations (a signal) in one medium, such as sound in the air, are translated to variations in some other domain, such as electricity in wires. The signals in the different domains are in one-to-one correspondence: one goes up, the other goes up. The word
analog
is related to the word
analogy

Analog and Noise: Hiss
A signal travels through the wires or air perfectly. At each step, little "noise" errors can creep in, like little wiggles around the true signal. Noise can sound like a
hiss
, such as you hear between stations on a radio.

Digitization/Sampling
An analog signal is brought into the computer by
digitization
. A chip called an
analog-to-digital (A/D) converter

samples the signal very rapidly over time, noting as a number the height of the curve from the midline. CD-quality digital audio samples the sound signal 44,000 times per second. Each sample is a whole number in the range −32,768 to 32,767 (this is the range of numbers that can be stored in 2 bytes).

Digitization is not quite perfect. The signal might have a little wiggle that happens so fast, the 44,000 samples/second are not fast enough to quite capture the wiggle perfectly. As a practical matter, though, the 44,000 samples per second is excellent at capturing the level of detail that humans can hear.

Essentially, digitization (A/D) translates a sound signal into just a series of numbers: 12,000, 12,002, 12,006, 12,007, 12,010, 12,005, 12,006, and so on. Once the sound is digitized to be a series of numbers, it is easy to store as computer data, which can be reproduced.
Digital Playback
Playing back the digital sound is just the reverse: a chip called a
digital-to-analog (D/A) converter

takes in a series of sample numbers, representing, for example, 44,000 samples/second, and constructs an electrical signal that matches those numbers over time. This reconstructs the original sound signal from the numbers.
Playing back the digital sound is just the reverse: a chip called a

takes in a series of sample numbers, representing, for example, 44,000 samples/second, and constructs an electrical signal that matches those numbers over time. This reconstructs the original sound signal from the numbers.
Digital vs. Errors

Suppose we are receiving sample numbers digitally over a wire, essentially just 0s and 1s. Say that a high voltage on the wire is 1, and low voltage is 0. What does that digital signal look like coming out of the wire?
If there is no noise, we can imagine the 0/1 signal coming out of the wire looking very clean. It's easy to tell when the voltage is low (0) versus high (1).
Now suppose there is terrible noise on the line. However, since we only need to distinguish two cases (low and high), it's
still easy
to distinguish the 0s from the 1s, even with terrible noise.
This illustrates how digitally handled signals can sound great and are error resistant compared to analog signals.
